subject: Technology
title: GPS Satellites and Everyday Life
description: A short lesson to help you apply GPS Satellites and Everyday Life.

hook.text: You open a map app and a blue dot shows exactly where you are. That dot depends on satellites 12,000 miles up.

buildup.text: 31 GPS satellites orbit Earth, each broadcasting its position and precise atomic clock time.

discovery.text: Your phone compares signals from four or more satellites and calculates your location through triangulation.

twist.text: The clocks must be accurate to billionths of a second. A one-microsecond error means 300 meters of drift.

climax.text: GPS enables navigation, farming, banking timestamps, and even earthquake detection.

punchline.text: Atomic clocks in space tell your phone where you are on Earth.

quiz.question: What would happen if GPS satellite clocks were off by one microsecond?
